qas.question: If a PCB is intended for use in an setting with extreme conditions, what would probably be applied?
A conformal coating can be applied by spraying the PCB or by doing what else to it?
The conformal coating can prevent leaking, shorts, and what other type of moisture damage?
What material was first used for conformal coating?
What action is made much more difficult for boards that have a conformal coating?
PABs are intended for what type of environment?
What type of coat encourages corrosion?

plausible_answers.text: servicing of the board is rendered extremely difficult

qas.question: The chief advantage to conformal coatings is what?
Which coatings are usually dips of dilute solutions of wax rubber?

context: PCBs intended for <b5_0>extreme<b5_0/> environments often have <b6_0>a <a0_0>conformal coating<b6_0/><a0_0/>, which is applied by <a1_0>dipping<a1_0/> or spraying after the components have been soldered. The coat prevents <a2_0>corrosion<a2_0/> and leakage currents or shorting due to condensation. The earliest conformal coats were <a3_0>wax<a3_0/>; <b8_0>modern conformal coats<b8_0/> are usually dips of dilute solutions of silicone rubber, polyurethane, acrylic, or epoxy. Another technique for applying a conformal coating is for plastic to be sputtered onto the PCB in a vacuum chamber. The chief disadvantage of conformal coatings is that <a4_0><b7_0>servicing<a4_0/> of the board is rendered extremely difficult<b7_0/>.
